title: Union Park (Chicago)
text:
Union Park is a <a href="municipal%20park">municipal park</a> in <a href="Chicago">Chicago</a>, <a href="Illinois">Illinois</a>, comprising .
Located in the <a href="Near%20West%20Side%2C%20Chicago">Near West Side</a>, the park is just south of <a href="Ashland%20%28CTA%20Green%20and%20Pink%20Lines%20station%29">Ashland/Lake station</a> on the <a href="Green%20Line%20%28CTA%29">Green</a> and <a href="Pink%20Line%20%28CTA%29">Pink</a> lines of the <a href="Chicago%20%27L%27">Chicago 'L'</a>, bordered by North Ashland Avenue on the west, <a href="Lake%20Street%20%28Chicago%29">West Lake Street</a> on the north, the diagonal <a href="Ogden%20Avenue">North Ogden Avenue</a> along most of the east border, and West Washington Boulevard on the south. The park has several large green fields used for demonstrations or various forms of <a href="American%20football">football</a>, playgrounds, a swimming pool, a fieldhouse, tennis courts, baseball fields, basketball courts.
While the name was chosen in 1853 in reference to the United States' <a href="federal%20union">federal union</a>, Union Park has a considerable labor history. The surrounding neighborhood is the home of most of the city's <a href="labor%20union">labor union</a> offices, including the <a href="United%20Electrical%2C%20Radio%20and%20Machine%20Workers%20of%20America">United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America</a>, the <a href="Teamsters">Teamsters</a>, <a href="LIUNA">LIUNA</a>, the <a href="Workers%20United">Workers United</a> Hall, and over a dozen others.
In the 1910s, the park was one of the only racially integrated parks in the city. In 2006, the park was the starting point for Chicago's wing of the <a href="2006%20immigration%20reform%20protests">2006 immigration reform protests</a>, including the <a href="Great%20American%20Boycott">Great American Boycott</a> on <a href="International%20Workers%20Day">International Workers Day</a>, which were the largest demonstrations in the history of Chicago to date. It is also the site of the annual <a href="Pitchfork%20Music%20Festival">Pitchfork Music Festival</a>, <a href="North%20Coast%20Music%20Festival">North Coast Music Festival</a>, and many other music festivals and <a href="political%20protests">political protests</a>. In 2006, the city commissioned a statue of <a href="James%20Connolly">James Connolly</a>, an <a href="Irish%20people">Irish</a> <a href="Irish%20republicanism">republican</a> and <a href="Marxist">Marxist</a> who was executed in 1916, on the south west corner.
